DOC.HEAD: Teens Volunteer for Alcohol-Free New Year's `Lock-In'
DOC.TEXT: High school students are going ahead with their New Year's Eve ``Lock-In,'' a drug- and alcohol-free party, even though far fewer students have signed up this year than last. As at similar parties, the doors at Masuk High School's second annual Lock-In will be kept shut so sober revelers can't go out and get in trouble. ``Call me crazy, but I think being sober and watching the ball drop is a lot more fun,'' said Lock-In Chairwoman Elizabeth Rhodes, a junior. About 140 students had signed up to attend the party at the high school, a smaller crowd than last year's 250, but enough to avoid canceling the party, she said. ``We fell somewhat short, but psychologically, I can't cancel out,'' she said. Students will ring in the new year with dancing, carnival games, sports, contests, pizza and door prizes that include a color television set.
